pros: Friendly people, emphasis on equality in the workplace

pros: If you’re working for Parking and Commuter Services, you can really do whatever you’d like in the kiosk when it’s slow or when you’re not helping anyone
cons: The two managers can get on power trips if they see something minor that they don’t like. I know two people who quit last semester because of them

pros: good resume builder and helps solidify relationships with professors

review_title: This place would be great with different adminstrators
pros: Students are great. Faculty are great.
cons: Administration is awful. They are all looking to move on to the next job. All want to move up and move elsewhere. Every decision is shortsighted because they won't be around for long.

pros: Meet new friends and make money all while staying on campus Made it easy to work around my schedule
cons: You can’t work more than 20 hours as a student

pros: Some of the pros of working at the SRC include a very fun and educational work environment. You're able to learn a lot about weightlifting and fitness in a non-judgemental environment. There is also room for growth, wage-wise, after a year or so.
cons: Once you are no longer a student, you cannot work here unless you take a management position which is typically unavailable.

pros: Coworkers were great, pay was decent starting out.
cons: As I took on more responsibilities, my pay was not increased. By the time I left, I was doing the job of about 3 people. We all actually got demoted because the company started to run out of money due to poor management. My original “benefits” (holiday pay only) were never reinstated even though I was told they would be. Work/life balance was also really difficult. The boss would blur those lines a lot by calling/texting/showing up to your house after work hours, and it was NOT okay. The boss also tried to get away with doing some shady stuff at the expense of the employees, but hopefully the work environment has improved since then.

pros: No pros for the NorCal VBOC program administered by HSU.
cons: The VBOC program has been mismanaged by the Executive Director for years, and she uses bait & switch tactics to recruit and then change the contract terms after hired. Extremely unprofessional.

pros: Good work life balance, stable employment, beautiful campus and health/fitness encouraged
cons: Difficult parking (not during covid).

job_title: Custodial Services Student Assistant in Arcata, CA
pros: Able to work on your own and complete your own tasks, not rushed, pretty decent pay for some spending money as a college student.
cons: Honestly no cons, had a really good supervisor. great experience for my first job

pros: Flexible hours that can be consistent
cons: Limited hours and seasonal opportunity

review_title: Great benefits and a creative variety of work.
pros: Great benefits and a creative variety of work. The students, staff and faculty are amazing. They offer flexible schedules, depending on your department, and the benefits are outstanding.
cons: Lower pay scale for my level of experience but the benefits are great.

pros: Nice work environment. Cares about safety of employees and students.

pros:
Pension includes health benefits for you and your spouse after retirement
Working in higher education
The students!
The campus is beautiful
The Arcata community forest is within walking distance of campus
cons: The uncertainty of the future of the university creates tension and low moral. Looming layoffs and not replacing key positions is creating burnout for employees. COVID has been a big disruption for a campus lagging in digital processes and procedures.

review_title: The best place to work in Humboldt County, but expect to be overworked and underpaid.
pros:
1) Rural atmosphere leads to a wonderful place to raise a family, if you like extra space and such. Little to no traffic and great air quality are a huge plus.
2) Excellent benefits package, one of the best in fact thanks to CalPERS mostly. Health, Vision, Dental, Pension, Fee Waiver, Vacation Accrual and Sick/Bereavement leave is wonderful. 
3) Fellow co-workers become great friends, some like family - people you can count on in a crisis.
4) Don't know the exact figure, but lots of employees went to school here and they are passionate about seeing the school exceed student expectations, they go the extra mile to make a difference.
cons:
1) Low salaries and little movement through established In-Range Progression Process (IRPs). This is because HSU is allowed to interpret their own subset of criteria for the process from the bigger CSU set. HSU only awards Staff IRPs for Retention, Extra Work/Responsibility and Equity. Most other CSUs have a larger subset of criteria so be sure you understand that there is little room for growth in your salary here.
2) After a while of working here you see patterns of problems and then solutions that previously failed come back around again and again. Tracking lessons learned would be helpful and would avoid this resource trap.
3) The longer you work here, the more difficult it is to leave and get a more reasonable salary. The low salary problem follows you into your next job offer.
4) If a co-worker leaves your department, by default you are assigned all of their work for no more compensation. Half the time it's a permanent increase in workload. After 2-3 of these it's not worth it anymore.
5) If you're a minority like me, it can be tough - although it is getting better in recent years thanks to new programs and energy towards inclusion.

pros: Humboldt is a beautiful area of California, and HSU is one of the few options locally to work in a meaningful place. The atmosphere on campus is very relaxed, and there are many friendly people working in all positions
cons: Recently (2013-onwards) there has been a distinct lack of leadership. The vacuums left by some higher positions leaving has lead to many different branches of campus no longer working each other as well. Career advancement is few and far between.

pros: The department I worked in was extremely flexible when it came to putting school before work. It made it so much less stressful to not have that worry.
cons: Not all departments appeared to be flexible on missing shifts because of school work, so check with the department head before accepting a position that requires too much of our time.

pros: My department is very understanding about being a student comes first.  The full-time staff are great to work with and it is great that many of them are Alumni, they love the school as much as the students do.
cons: Housing in Arcata is way overpriced, the homeless/transient/tweaker issues that the county is experiencing, and higher than California average gas prices begin to wear on the wallet.  A trip to the river or beach makes all that go away, thankfully!

review_title: Less bureaucratic than many other universities, but issues between departments
pros: The people are pretty nice and the atmosphere is relatively relaxed for a university
cons: It can be a bit of a popularity contest. If you aren't one of the prized employees it can be easy to be neglected. And there is animosity between some departments.

pros: Some of the kindest, hardworking people you could ever meet. Many people genuinely care about the students--they REALLY love the students.
cons: Too much self righteousness and white liberalism. A few white women think it is appropriate to speak on behalf of POC, making life unbearable. Too many back room deals, while preaching transparency. They just don't see their own hypocrisy.

job_title: Administrative Assistant, Physical Services Department in Arcata, CA
pros: Excellent staff.  Truly enjoyed working with forward thinking, problem solving individuals.  I wanted to learn about the architectural plans and was trained in how to read and disseminate information.  I was also given the opportunity to assist a Project Manager, which was very enriching.
cons: Campus parking is always an issue but as long as you don't mind walking a bit, not bad.

pros: Flexible schedule, work between classes, good employees. Really a great job for a student. Can learn a lot from the employees.
cons: The pay is minimum, but you don't have as many taxes. Pay is monthly, which is really straining when going to school.

pros: location-- beach and redwoods.  Pretty laid back work environment (it is okay to wear birkenstocks).  Good environmental resources programs.
cons: Hard to move ahead.  Many people stay for life, so there are not a lot of opportunities, and it seems that they take external hires more frrequently.  The vision of the university is changing, and not everyone is on the same page.

pros: Most flexible work schedule, and the friendliest, upbeat colleagues imaginable.Department chair is the best leader and employer one could ask for.
cons: The pay is like flipping burgers.

pros: I worked on a number of student run and funded programs that were fantastic. I highly recommend getting involved and getting paid to do something that will benefit your resume!
cons: Lack of continuity due to having to leave an intern position once graduated.

job_title: Residence Advisor and Cafeterias Worker in Arcata, CA
pros: As an RA: housing and food program paid for,  comprehensive training,  close knit community. At the cafeteria: flexibility with work schedule.
cons: Low compensation,  constantly on the job as an RA, tedium during work at the cafeteria.

review_title: warm culture, culture of acceptance, ample opportunities for more training

review_title: A great place to work, lack of advancement opportunities

cons: Limited career opportunities, long distance from metropolitan centers, lack of diversity, limited funds, aging facilities.

pros: Beautiful Area, great piano department, friendly environment.
